docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This is a very simple package containing two modules that implement vehicle and car classes. The documentation includes the API docstrings for the modules and a demo example in Jupyter notebook.

docs.title: System structure
docs.text:

flowchart LR
subgraph Vehicle
num1[(num_of_wheels)]
end
subgraph Car
num2[(num_of_wheels)]
brand[(brand)]
drive[drive]

end
Car --inherits--> Vehicle

docs.title: Car
docs.text:
Bases: Vehicle

A car class which inherits from Vehicle.

Source code in src/car.py 
class Car(Vehicle):
'''
    A car class which inherits from Vehicle.
    '''
    def __init__(self, num_of_wheels: int, brand: str):
'''
        Initialise a car with the given number of wheels.

        Args:
            num_of_wheels (int): the number of wheels a vehicle has
        '''
        super().__init__(num_of_wheels)
        self._brand = brand


    @property
    def brand(self) -> str:
'''
        Return the brand of the car.

        Returns:
            str: the brand of the car
        '''
        return self._brand

    def drive(self, num_of_miles: float) -> None:
'''
        Drive the vehicle for a given number of miles

        Args:
            num_of_miles (float): how far to drive the vehicle
        '''
        print('starting engine')
        print(f'driving forward for {num_of_miles} mile(s)')
        print('stopping')

def __init__(self, num_of_wheels: int, brand: str):
'''
    Initialise a car with the given number of wheels.

    Args:
        num_of_wheels (int): the number of wheels a vehicle has
    '''
    super().__init__(num_of_wheels)
    self._brand = brand

def drive(self, num_of_miles: float) -> None:
'''
    Drive the vehicle for a given number of miles

    Args:
        num_of_miles (float): how far to drive the vehicle
    '''
    print('starting engine')
    print(f'driving forward for {num_of_miles} mile(s)')
    print('stopping')

docs.title: Vehicle
docs.text:
This is a vehicle class. It has a number of wheels.

Source code in src/vehicle.py 
class Vehicle():
'''
    This is a vehicle class. It has a number of wheels.
    '''

    def __init__(self, num_of_wheels: int):
'''
        To initialise a vehicle by supplying the number of wheels

        Args:
            num_of_wheels (int): number of wheels a vehicle has
        '''
        self._num_of_wheels = num_of_wheels

    @property
    def num_of_wheels(self) -> int:
'''
        To access the number of wheels a vehicle can have

        Returns:
            int: the number of wheels specified
        '''
        return self._num_of_wheels

docs.title: Car class demo
docs.text:
In [1]: Copied! 
from car import Car

fancy_car = Car(num_of_wheels=6, brand='POSH')
print(f'My fancy {fancy_car.brand} car has {fancy_car.num_of_wheels} wheels')
from car import Car fancy_car = Car(num_of_wheels=6, brand='POSH') print(f'My fancy {fancy_car.brand} car has {fancy_car.num_of_wheels} wheels') 
My fancy POSH car has 6 wheels
In [10]: Copied! 
import seaborn as sns

sns.barplot(x=['fancy_car.num_of_wheels'], y=[fancy_car.num_of_wheels])

docs.title: Car class demo¶
docs.text: In this notebook, I show you how to get the brand and the number of wheels of a car created.
